threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Can't read directory

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects malicious macro / powershell in Office document
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects Word Document with PowerShell URLDownloadToFile
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious UTF16 and Base64 encoded PowerShell code that starts with a $ sign and a single char variable
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macros extracted from the document appear to be benign and do not exhibit any signs of malicious intent. The macro behavior includes functions related to manipulating text formatting within a table in a Word document, as well as a function for downloading files from a URL using the URLDownloadToFile API. Additionally, there is a command button that triggers the ShowHideTable1 subroutine to show or hide specific table elements.

The Document_Open() subroutine contains PowerShell commands encoded in base64 strings, which are executed when the document is opened. These PowerShell commands seem to be related to setting window properties and executing certain actions, but they do not indicate any malicious activity.

Overall, based on the analysis of the macros, there are no clear indicators of malicious behavior present in the code.

The provided macros exhibit several indicators of malicious intent:

1. Obfuscated Code: The macros contain heavily obfuscated code, making it difficult to understand their true functionality. This obfuscation is often used to bypass security measures and hide malicious behavior.

2. Base64 Decoding: The macros decode a large base64-encoded string, which is a common technique used to hide malicious payloads. The decoded string contains additional obfuscated code and suspicious function calls.

3. Suspicious Function Calls: The macros make suspicious function calls, such as `URLDownloadToFile` and `Shell`, which can be used to download and execute arbitrary files from the internet. These functions are often associated with malware and macro viruses.

4. Attempts at Persistence: The macros attempt to create a scheduled task named "Auto_Open" to ensure their persistence on the system. This scheduled task would automatically run the malicious code every time the user opens a document.

5. Manipulation of Macro Security Settings: The macros attempt to disable macro security settings, making it easier for other malicious macros to run without user intervention.

6. Writing Entries in the Windows Registry: The macros write entries in the Windows registry, which can be used to modify system settings and potentially compromise the security of the computer.

7. Self-Replication and Propagation Mechanisms: The macros contain code that attempts to replicate themselves and spread to other documents, exhibiting characteristics of a macro virus.

8. Disabling Alerts and Screen Updating: The macros disable alerts and screen updating, preventing the user from seeing any warnings or notifications about the malicious activities being performed.

These indicators strongly suggest that the provided macros are malicious and should be treated with caution. It is recommended to use a robust antivirus program to scan and remove any potential threats associated with these macros.
